data.text: We have a trailer and panniers. The trouble with the trailer, in my experience, has been user error. It's way to easy to overload it. The other issue can be mobility in small spaces. Otherwise, it's great.

data.text: For a new trailer the Burley Coho XC is the one to have - excellent and brilliant design. The BOB trailers were very good indeed (I have a Yak and an Ibex) but are now discontinued.
data.author: Tony Mitchelhill

data.text: I just bought a weehoo that is pretty sweet for pulling kids. Might make a good cargo trailer without the baby seats.

data.text: had a BOB for years, my advice get a Burley NOMAD
data.author: Dennis Peterson

data.text: I have the Topeak Journey which is all aluminum and looks like a more refined version of a Bob. Haven‚Äôt had the opportunity to long tour with it but did some trial pulls loaded and it felt very manageable. No climbs were involved so that might be another story. I really should try to find someone who can use it since I just don‚Äôt have time to tour for a couple more years.

data.text: I have a BoB Yak...love it

data.text: Indeed, superb trailer but now discontinued.
data.author: Tony Mitchelhill

data.text: Tons available for sale all over the place.. Cheers
data.author: Randy Anthony

data.text:
discontinued means no longer manufactured. Try buying one - a quick search around the internet reveals some patchy remaining inventory here and there around the globe. I purchased the Ibex in December 2020 having learned that manufacture had ceased and the only source of supply I could find then was a dealer in Como Italy who had 8 remaining in stock at that time. It seems apparent that you don't believe me so take up that argument with these people: https://www.campfirecycling.com/product-category/closeouts/trailer-closeouts/bob-trailers
BOB Trailer Parts Closeouts - CampfireCycling.com
campfirecycling.com
data.author: Tony Mitchelhill

data.text: Extra wheel can take a extra wheel and tyre setup with you that way and a extra set of panniers you can even take a extra hub with gears and brakes with you that way
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: Bob trailers are great but two items sway my feelings 1. 19 extra pounds of well built trailer ,2. really expensive . Going on the flats with any trailer is a breeze but the first slope you come to the trailer weight is really noticeable. Low gears come in real handy and your average speed that you were so proud of on the flats ,dwindles .
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: I‚Äôm thinking about camping and touring, not speed.
data.author: Donald Ewen

data.text: Yes I realize that. Drudgery as you pedal slowly up one of our mountain passes will quickly impress you that trailer weight vs pannier weight does indeed make a difference. However I imagine you are riding a diamond frame not a recumbent and your pannier size is regulated by heel strike whereas mine is not. We have a tendency to fill our trailers or panniers with stuff because there is lots of room, but as I discovered on one tour if you go to essentials only ,that leaves lots of room for Broccoli which as we all know is the staff of life!
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: Hello, a sarcastic remark which I apologise for in advance "are you moving house!". My wife an I travelled for weeks on a tandem with four pannier bags. We had a tent, sleeping bags, foam mattresses and some utensils. Waterproofs, several sets of clothes plus none cycling footwear. We didn't cook food. I realise that autumn/winter touring requires heavier sleeping bags and warmer clothing. I did think about a trailer once. It is similar to the choice between campervan and caravan. I chose the campervan approach!
data.author: Michael Woolaghan

data.text: My wife has a problem with panniers so she carries minimally and I carry on both front and back. I try to keep my cargo weight to a 35lb max. I also carry a guitar and I also like to cook when I travel. (None of that freeze dried guess-a-meal)The trailer is what I‚Äôm hopeful will do it all with only one set of panniers. After all the comments I think it‚Äôs a Burley Coho XC.
data.author: Donald Ewen

data.text: what's best for you is not what's best for all riders perhaps?
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: always
data.author: Donald Ewen

data.text: Burley Coho works well. I don't pack much.
data.author: Anthony Medina

data.text: How does your bike handle with a heavier load?
data.author: Dan Hurley

data.text: I‚Äôve carried the load for a while and The bikes I‚Äôve got are old and steel so they can handle the weight. The more I answer people‚Äôs comments the more I realize, I think I want the trailer more for my guitar than anything else.
data.author: Donald Ewen

data.text: With a gross 40 lbs or so it's not bad. It's steady, tracks in a straight line nicely, turns at speed without feeling like anything is going to bust loose. I've used this in a group ride with bikepackers safely and comfortably, for me and for them.
data.author: Anthony Medina

data.text: Thanks for the review. So far the Burley is in my top two and leading!
data.author: Donald Ewen
